welcome_to_alloy.title: Welcome to Alloy
content: Alloy is a framework-agnostic UI Library containing reusable styles, web components, and guidelines.

content.title: Content
content: Components: Our collection of framework-agnostic web components designed for symplr.
Theme: Our foundational styling for Alloy components and symplr applications.
Iconography: Our extensive library of icons for use in symplr applications.

principles.title: Principles
content: Curation over invention: Alloy gathers and refines the best solutions from across our portfolios and the web more than it invents new solutions. Invention emerges from collaboration with product teams, SMEs, and usability experts.

Quality over speed: Alloy favors considered selection and enhancement of the best solutions over rushing them into the design system. New or anticipated Alloy features should rarely be in the critical path for a product release.
Pragmatism over ideology: Alloy accommodates the realities of platform or resource limitations and bends guidance to the doable rather than the perfect.
Reuse over one-off: Alloy provides guidelines and solutions for interactions that are common and/or ubiquitous. One-off scenarios are the domain of product teams.

curation_over_invention.title: Curation over invention
content: Alloy gathers and refines the best solutions from across our portfolios and the web more than it invents new solutions. Invention emerges from collaboration with product teams, SMEs, and usability experts.

quality_over_speed.title: Quality over speed
content: Alloy favors considered selection and enhancement of the best solutions over rushing them into the design system. New or anticipated Alloy features should rarely be in the critical path for a product release.

pragmatism_over_ideology.title: Pragmatism over ideology
content: Alloy accommodates the realities of platform or resource limitations and bends guidance to the doable rather than the perfect.

reuse_over_one_off.title: Reuse over one-off
content: Alloy provides guidelines and solutions for interactions that are common and/or ubiquitous. One-off scenarios are the domain of product teams.

accessibility.title: Accessibility
content: Though the Alloy design system is not fully ADA compliant at this time, the Alloy team considers this a high priority initiative and is actively engaged in this effort.
Many components are already keyboard navigable and have been tested for color contrast.

resources.title: Resources
content: Confluence
FAQs
GitHub
Support form
Support channel
Alloy team sprint review

layout3.title: Layout
content: Breakpoints define how the display property should be defined depending on the size.
To avoid jumps and shifts when a user moves from one page of your application to another, the Alloy design system advocates for the use of a layout grid when designing your application.

breakpoints.title: Breakpoints
content: Small devices (landscape phones): 640px and up
Medium devices (tablets): 768px and up
Large devices (desktops): 1024px and up
Extra large devices (large desktops): 1280px and up
Double extra large devices (Ultra large desktops): 1536px and up

grid_guidelines.title: Grid Guidelines
content: Before constructing your application pages, consider the following recommendations with regard to the spacing of design elements.

standard_pages.title: Standard pages
content: Example: Pages 1280px and up
Use a 12-column layout grid with 56px margins and 16px gutters.
Align with the first column of the 12-column layout grid.
Note: An exception to this rule would be in cases where primary navigation may hug the left side of the application.
Define the number of columns to be displayed instead of column width.

mobile.title: Mobile
content: Use a 4-column layout grid with 16px margins and 16px gutters.
Define the number of columns to be displayed instead of column width.
Note: Top navigation and footer are currently in development.

spacing_guidelines.title: Spacing Guidelines
content: For pages with breadcrumbs: 24px between application header and breadcrumbs, 16px between breadcrumb and top of page heading, optional 4px between page heading and instructional text.
If tabs exist below the page heading: 16px between page heading and tabs, 16px between tabs and grid or additional content element.
If no tabs exist below the page heading: 24px between page heading and next content element, 16px between content element and grid or additional content element.
For pages without breadcrumbs: 24px between application header and top of page heading, optional 4px between page heading and instructional text.

the_8_rule.title: The 8-Rule
content: When in doubt, use multiples of eight to space the elements in your design.
This includes all padding and margin between elements.
Spacing values: 4px (xxs), 8px (xs), 16px (sm), 24px (md), 48px (lg), 96px (xl)

typography_tokens.title: Typography tokens
content:
These lists contain all the typography tokens used within the Alloy theme.
The values of these tokens should not be used directly, instead components
and applications should use the corresponding CSS variables.
Note: All tokens are mapped directly to CSS variables.

tokens.title: Tokens
content:
These lists contain all the color tokens used within the Alloy theme.
The hex values of these colors should not be used directly, instead components
and applications should use the corresponding CSS variables.
There are two categories of color tokens that comprise the theme. Alias and Component tokens.

Alias tokens are used to define the specific cases in which a referenced
color value should be used. Alias token names reference what the token is
intended for (e.g., backgrounds, borders, text, data visualizations,
graphics, and status) and never the actual value (e.g., skyblue-tint-10).

Component tokens are used for specific components (e.g., data tables,
buttons, and links) where overwriting specific values may be needed.
Component token names reference what the token is intended for (e.g.,
table and button backgrounds, borders, and text) and never the actual
value (e.g., mediumblue-shade-70).

semantic_slots_deprecated.title: Semantic slots (Deprecated)
content: After much thought and consideration, Alloy is no longer maintaining and supporting semantic slots.

If you've been using semantic slots for colors, we'd encourage you to begin using the color tokens outlined above. These can be consumed much easier with no need for a CSS pre-processor (e.g. Sass). Semantic slots will be removed in the next major release.
For information on migrating from semantic slots to tokens, check out our color migration guide

These lists contain all the semantic slots used within the Alloy theme.
Components and applications should not use the hex values of these colors
directly, Instead they should use the provided get-semantic-slot
scss function

layout2.title: Layout

breakpoints2.title: Breakpoints
content: Breakpoints define how the display property should be defined depending on the size.

guidelines.title: Guidelines
content: Before constructing your application pages, consider the following recommendations with regard to the spacing of design elements:
For pages with breadcrumbs use ...
24 px between application header and breadcrumbs16 px between breadcrumb and top of page headingOptional: 4 px between page heading and instructional text
If tabs exist below the page heading (or instructional text):
16 px between page heading (or instructional text) and tabs16 px between tabs and grid or additional content element
If no tabs exist below the page heading (or instructional text):
24 px between page heading (or instructional text) and next content element16 px between content element and grid or additional content element
For pages without breadcrumbs use ...
24 px between application header and top of page headingOptional: 4 px between page heading and instructional text
If tabs exist below the page heading (or instructional text):
16 px between page heading (or instructional text) and tabs16 px between tabs and grid or additional content element
If no tabs exist below the page heading (or instructional text):
24 px between page heading (or instructional text) and next content element16 px between content element and grid or additional content element

standard_pages2.title: Standard pages
content: Example: Pages 1280 px+
Use a 12-column layout grid with 56 px (margins) and 16 px (gutters).Align with the first column of the 12-column layout grid.
Note: An exception to this rule would be in cases where primary navigation may hug the left side of the application.
Define the number of columns to be displayed instead of column width.

mobile2.title: Mobile
content: Use a 4-column layout grid with 16 px (margins) and 16 px (gutters).Define the number of columns to be displayed instead of column width.
Note: Top navigation and footer are currently in development.

the_8_rule2.title: The "8-Rule"
content: When in doubt, use multiples of eight to space the elements in your design.
This includes all padding/margin between elements.
SpacingSass variable4 pxget-spacing('xxs')8 pxget-spacing('xs')16 pxget-spacing('sm')24 pxget-spacing('md')48 pxget-spacing('lg')96 pxget-spacing('xl')

usage2.title: Usage
content: A Button is used to execute or initiate an action. Before using the Button component, consider the following usage guidelines:

use_when2.title: Use when ...
content: A component is needed to act as a call to action.A component is needed to move a user through a sequence of screens.

do_not_use_when2.title: Do not use when ...
content: A user may select from multiple actions on a page. Consider using a Quick Menu or Tools Menu instead.A user must complete a process. Consider using a Stepper instead.
The Alloy Design System offers four types of buttons. These include: Primary, Secondary, Tertiary, and Icon. Guidelines for using these button types are defined in the following table.

ButtonUse whenDo not use whenPrimaryUse as the principal call to action on a screen. Ideally, primary buttons should only appear once per screen (not including the application header or in a modal dialog). Remaining calls to action should be represented as lower emphasis buttons.A user should navigate to a different screen. Consider using a Link instead.SecondaryAn additional call to action must be represented.A primary button has not been used.TertiaryA third call to action must be represented.A primary and secondary button have not been used.IconA call to action is needed, usually within a Data Grid.

format2.title: Format
content: When formatting the Button component, keep the following do's and don'ts in mind:

Do
   Grouping:Button groups should be right-aligned at the bottom.Spacing of 16 px should be used between buttons.Icons:Only use a right-pointing arrow when placed to right of button label.Only use one icon at a time within the same button.Only use the "si-loader" icon to represent loading action.Only use the "si-sparkles" icon in the symplrAI button.*Reach out to the Alloy team for permission to use any other icon style in this placement.Labels:Should be displayed in a single line and not wrap.Should be in sentence case.Should contain no more than two words, if possible.Should reflect action to be completed when pressed.
   
    
    Don't
   Colors:Change the button color to red to indicate destructive action.Change the colors used in any button type.Icons:Use a right icon and count within the same button.Use both an assigned and free icon within the same button.Use more than one icon at a time within the same button.Labels:Use title case for button labels.Wrap button label text.Size:Mix button sizes in the same component.
For formatting recommendations for each button type, please refer to the following table.

ButtonLabelsPlacementPrimaryIf more than one word, only the first word is capitalized.Example: "Save report"Use to represent action of primary button.Example: "Save"The primary button should be place on the far right.SecondaryIf more than one word, only the first word is capitalized.Example: "Learn more"Use to represent opposite action of primary button.Example: "Cancel"Place secondary buttons to the left of primary buttons.TertiaryIf more than one word, only the first word is capitalized.Example: "Search providers"Place tertiary buttons to the left of secondary and primary buttons.IconIcon buttons may, or may not, include labels.Recommend limiting amount of text to one word.May be used inside a Data Grid.
CAUTION: Stand-alone icons may not be used to trigger an action. To trigger an action, you must use the Icon Button component, as noted above.

rect{opacity:0.5;background-color:rgba(232,232,232, 0.8);fill:rgba(232,232,232, 0.8);}#mermaid-1760709360809 :root{--mermaid-font-family:"trebuchet ms",verdana,arial,sans-serif;}sympl-tagsympl-icon
Built with StencilJSUsageA Tag is used to categorize information or display the status of an element. The Alloy Tag component has been built with the following properties that may be configured to suit your specific needs:severity (critical, draft, info, new, primary, success, warning)size (sm, md, lg)variants (default, inverse, text)NOTE: The Tag component is not interactive.Before using the Tag component, consider the following usage guidelines:
Use when …A component is needed that will alert a user to new or important information (e.g., a new provider record).A component is needed that will display the status of an element (e.g., an expired license).A component is needed that will visually categorize multiple types of information (e.g., active and inactive coverage).Do not use when …A component is needed that can be dismissed/removed by the user (e.g., a filter). Consider using a Chip instead.A component is needed that, when clicked, will navigate the user to a different page or separate tab. Consider using a Link instead.A component is needed to represent a number or count of items. Consider using a Count instead.A component is needed to represent a selected filter (e.g., above a Data Grid) or date (e.g., within a Non-contiguous Date Picker). Consider using a Chip instead.FormatWhen formatting the Tag, keep the following do's and don'ts in mind.
   
    
    Do
   Ensure Tag text is concise, in all caps, and fewer than 20 characters, if possible.If displaying an icon, ensure it corresponds to the Tag severity as noted in the Icons section below.Keep number of Tags on a page to a minimum so their importance is not diluted.
   
    
    Don't
   Display too many Tags on a single page.Include a dismiss/remove "x" icon, as Tags are not actionable.Place in the same container as a button, or buttons.Programmatically change the colors used in the Tag.IconsTo offer additional flexibility, the Tag component has been built in such a way that the icon and severity have not been coupled. However, if using the Tag component to display a standard status, we strongly recommend its corresponding icon be used (refer to the following table).SeverityPreferred iconcriticalsi-alert-triangledraftsi-file-textinfosi-info-squarenewsi-megaphone-2successsi-check-circle-3warningsi-alert-diamondResourcesPrimeNGYou must enable third-party cookies to interact with Figma.Accessibility requirements based on WCAG guidelines for this component are in development.

This is required.stringundefinedvariantvariantVariant of the tag."default" \| "inverse" \| "text"'default'

graph.title: Graph

rect{opacity:0.5;background-color:rgba(232,232,232, 0.8);fill:rgba(232,232,232, 0.8);}#mermaid-1760709360809 :root{--mermaid-font-family:"trebuchet ms",verdana,arial,sans-serif;}sympl-tagsympl-icon

usage.title: Usage
content: A Tag is used to categorize information or display the status of an element. The Alloy Tag component has been built with the following properties that may be configured to suit your specific needs:
severity (critical, draft, info, new, primary, success, warning)size (sm, md, lg)variants (default, inverse, text)
NOTE: The Tag component is not interactive.
Before using the Tag component, consider the following usage guidelines:

use_when.title: Use when …
content: A component is needed that will alert a user to new or important information (e.g., a new provider record).A component is needed that will display the status of an element (e.g., an expired license).A component is needed that will visually categorize multiple types of information (e.g., active and inactive coverage).

do_not_use_when.title: Do not use when …
content: A component is needed that can be dismissed/removed by the user (e.g., a filter). Consider using a Chip instead.A component is needed that, when clicked, will navigate the user to a different page or separate tab. Consider using a Link instead.A component is needed to represent a number or count of items. Consider using a Count instead.A component is needed to represent a selected filter (e.g., above a Data Grid) or date (e.g., within a Non-contiguous Date Picker). Consider using a Chip instead.

format3.title: Format
content: When formatting the Tag, keep the following do's and don'ts in mind.

Do
   Ensure Tag text is concise, in all caps, and fewer than 20 characters, if possible.If displaying an icon, ensure it corresponds to the Tag severity as noted in the Icons section below.Keep number of Tags on a page to a minimum so their importance is not diluted.
   
    
    Don't
   Display too many Tags on a single page.Include a dismiss/remove "x" icon, as Tags are not actionable.Place in the same container as a button, or buttons.Programmatically change the colors used in the Tag.

icons.title: Icons
content: To offer additional flexibility, the Tag component has been built in such a way that the icon and severity have not been coupled. However, if using the Tag component to display a standard status, we strongly recommend its corresponding icon be used (refer to the following table).
SeverityPreferred iconcriticalsi-alert-triangledraftsi-file-textinfosi-info-squarenewsi-megaphone-2successsi-check-circle-3warningsi-alert-diamond

form_design.title: Form design
content: UsageStyleGuidelinesNon-editable input fieldsIf you aren't sure whether a non-editable input field should appear disabled or read-only, ask yourself:Does the user need to see the non-editable input field and/or its contents?If "No" then it should not appear on the form.If "Yes" then move to the next question.Do the contents (whether filled or blank) of the non-editable input field need to be sent upon submission of the form?If "No" then the input field should appear as disabled. (Alloy styling is 50% opacity.)If "Yes" then the input field should appear as read-only. (Alloy styling is using the read-only interaction state.)Comparison of interaction statesRefer to the following table for additional clarification on the differences between an input field's enabled, disabled, and read-only interaction states.EnabledRead-onlyDisabledCan be edited Can be focused upon Can generate UI events Can interact with scrollbar Can select contents FormatWhen designing a form, keep the following do's and don'ts in mind:Button and field labels
Ensure a button label describes the button action.Label every field (sentence case).Keep labels short, if possible.
Use placeholders in place of a label.Label field and button labels in all caps.Use long labels.Checkboxes and radio groups
Align checkboxes and radio groups vertically, if possible.Display all radio group options unless greater than six.**Consider using a dropdown instead.
Display options in a radio group if there are more than six.Fields

Design a field's length to match the intended input.Group fields that are related.Spacing (vertical) between fields should be 16 px.Use the appropriate input component.Use dropdown component if number of options is >5.** If number of options is >25, include a search option.Layout

Use a one-column layout, except in cases where a multi-column layout is logical for proximal placement of like fields, and is possible given the device upon which the form is displayed (e.g., desktop or tablet).
Use a multi-column layout, if possible.Required fieldsWhen formatting a field that is required, keep these do's and don'ts in mind:

Add padding between fields to prevent content shifting.Error message should indicate the field is required.Error message should replace Helper text (if present).Error validation occurs after user interacts with field.Include an asterisk to the right of the field label. Asterisk color: --alloy-alias-color-status-critical-strongReference: Form design best practicesIn development.

non_editable_input_fields.title: Non-editable input fields
content: If you aren't sure whether a non-editable input field should appear disabled or read-only, ask yourself:

Does the user need to see the non-editable input field and/or its contents?If "No" then it should not appear on the form.If "Yes" then move to the next question.Do the contents (whether filled or blank) of the non-editable input field need to be sent upon submission of the form?If "No" then the input field should appear as disabled. (Alloy styling is 50% opacity.)If "Yes" then the input field should appear as read-only. (Alloy styling is using the read-only interaction state.)

comparison_of_interaction_states.title: Comparison of interaction states
content: Refer to the following table for additional clarification on the differences between an input field's enabled, disabled, and read-only interaction states.
EnabledRead-onlyDisabledCan be edited Can be focused upon Can generate UI events Can interact with scrollbar Can select contents

format.title: Format
content: When designing a form, keep the following do's and don'ts in mind:

button_and_field_labels.title: Button and field labels
content: Ensure a button label describes the button action.Label every field (sentence case).Keep labels short, if possible.
Use placeholders in place of a label.Label field and button labels in all caps.Use long labels.

checkboxes_and_radio_groups.title: Checkboxes and radio groups
content: Align checkboxes and radio groups vertically, if possible.Display all radio group options unless greater than six.**Consider using a dropdown instead.
Display options in a radio group if there are more than six.

fields.title: Fields
content: Design a field's length to match the intended input.Group fields that are related.Spacing (vertical) between fields should be 16 px.Use the appropriate input component.Use dropdown component if number of options is >5.** If number of options is >25, include a search option.

layout.title: Layout
content: Use a one-column layout, except in cases where a multi-column layout is logical for proximal placement of like fields, and is possible given the device upon which the form is displayed (e.g., desktop or tablet).
Use a multi-column layout, if possible.

required_fields.title: Required fields
content: When formatting a field that is required, keep these do's and don'ts in mind:

Add padding between fields to prevent content shifting.Error message should indicate the field is required.Error message should replace Helper text (if present).Error validation occurs after user interacts with field.Include an asterisk to the right of the field label. Asterisk color: --alloy-alias-color-status-critical-strong
Reference: Form design best practices
